hint.txt: No instructions are processing arithmetic or math operations on FP elements. This loop is probably writing/copying data or processing integer elements.

hint.title: Matching between your loop (in the source code) and the binary loop
hint.txt:
The binary loop does not contain any FP arithmetical operations.
The binary loop is loading 16 bytes.
The binary loop is storing 8 bytes.

hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor. This can be done manually. Or by recompiling with -funroll-loops and/or -floop-unroll-and-jam. Or with the unroll (resp. unroll_and_jam) directive on top of the inner (resp. surrounding) loop. You can enforce an unroll factor: #pragma GCC unroll N

hint.txt: Loop body is too small to efficiently use resources.

expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 1.60 cycles. At this rate:
  • 7% of peak load performance is reached (10.00 out of 128.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
  • 7% of peak store performance is reached (5.00 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 1.60 to 1.50 cycles (1.07x speedup).

expert.title: ASM code
expert.txt:
In the binary file, the address of the loop is: 4f50fa
InstructionNb FUP0P1P2P3P4P5P6P7P8P9LatencyRecip. throughput
DECQ (%RDI)30.250.250.500.500.500.250.250.500.500.5010.60
JE 4f51a3 <tupledealloc+0x183>10.50000000.5000000.50-1
SUB $0x1,%R1210.250.250000.250.2500010.25
JB 4f5118 <tupledealloc+0xf8>10.50000000.5000000.50
MOV 0x18(%RBP,%R12,8),%RDI1000.500.5000000020.50
TEST %RDI,%RDI10.250.250000.250.2500010.25
JNE 4f50fa <tupledealloc+0xda>10.50000000.5000000.50-1

header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.00 out of 64.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
    • recompile with fassociative-math (included in Ofast or ffast-math) to extend loop vectorization to FP reductions.
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
8 data elements could be processed at once in vector registers.
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 1.60 to 0.20 cycles (8.00x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.
